description: From Middle English bawde, baude, from Old French baud (“bold, lively, jolly, gay”). Doublet of bold.

adjectives.description: bawd (comparative more bawd, superlative most bawd)

entries.meaning: (now archaic or historical) A person who keeps a house of prostitution, or procures women for prostitution; a procurer, a madame.
examples: As Whores decay'd and past their Labours, / Turn Bawds, and so assist their Neighbours.

verbs.description: bawd (third-person singular simple present bawds, present participle bawding, simple past and past participle bawded)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To procure women for lewd purposes.
